Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Embedded Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning for Drone Vision
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is that it will enable artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML) solutions to be implemented in embedded and remote devices. It provides the means to make any camera, remote sensor, or detector truly intelligent and capable of discernment and prediction; any device that has already been electronically equipped will have the potential to utilize decision making intellect. It will be a catalyst in making AI/ML truly ubiquitous and a commodity of the human experience. Intelligent sensors will help make the world safer, cameras will be able to detect anomalies and alert authorities before tragedies, and detectors will be able to predict emergencies instead of simply telemetering data. Economically, through human assistance, embedded AI/ML will enable society to be more efficient and produce greater yield. This has the potential to be a transformative technology that impacts multiple levels of society.

This I-Corps project further develops an implementation of artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML) directly as a hardware circuit. AI/ML have revolutionized several technical industries such as voice recognition, image processing, healthcare, and personalized advertisements. AI/ML operates by training a mathematical model, often a combination of non-linear functions, to make inferences about the model's environment. However, AI/ML has been primarily restricted to cloud-based applications with large quantities of computing resources. In contrast, this technology implements the AI/ML model as hardware circuit that fits within a single integrated circuit. This project builds off previous technical accomplishments that implemented software design principles, such as extensibility, service-oriented architecture, modularity, and loose coupling, in hardware design through software assisted compilation. Creating a software aid to automatically restructure the hardware design enabled the hardware to change much more dynamically according to a series of parameters. By applying similar techniques to AI/ML, the technology will be able deconstruct and analyze the AI/ML model, and through a series of algorithms construct a matching hardware circuit.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through the project we completed 123 customer discovery interviews. We interviewed individuals involved in Search and Rescue, Coast Guard, and Border Security. Our initial hypothesis was that the technology could be attached to an unmanned aerial vehicle for search and rescue operations. To test this hypothesis, we interviewed individuals in emergency response, search and rescue, police, firefighters, and SWAT. Through the customer discovery process we realized that this commercialization path was unlikely due to the funding available to these agencies. Each of the agencies has very limited funding and prioritizes crucial equipment. Our technology would be impactful to their mission, however it would not currently be viewed as essential.

Once we decided that search and rescue would not be a likely commercialization path, we pivoted to the US Coast Guard (USCG). Our new hypothesis was that the USCG could use this technology to enhance their current instruments and enable them to more accurately locate people in need of rescue. We interviewed USCG personnel in Florida, California, and Texas to test the new hypothesis. Our interviews showed that the USCG did have an unmet need for this technology, however the USCG would probably not be an initial customer. We learned that the USCG prefers to use proven technologies and is unlikely to adopt new technologies on the market.

We again had to pivot and looked for new applications. We decided that Border Security may have a similar need. Through customer discovery interviews with Border Security we determined that they are a viable customer. This showed that the technology has strong commercialization potential. Border Security searches all day and night to protect the US border and needs technology to enhance its search capabilities. In addition, the Border Security is continually looking for new tools to enhance their abilities. Ultimately, through our customer discovery, we determined that our technology can greatly impact Border Security’s mission, and Border Security has interest in its application.


Last Modified: 08/17/2020
Modified by: Rodney Boehm
